qas.question: What group were the Hashimiyya a sect of?
Of what clan were the Abbasids members of?
What year saw the death of Abu Hashim?
Who was named successor by Abu Hashim?
What was a sub-sect of the Hashimiyya movement?
Who named Muhammad ibn al-Hanafiyya as his successor?
What failed to rally the supporters of the failed revolt?

plausible_answers.text: the supporters of the failed revolt of Mukhtar

qas.question: Who represented themselves as the supporters of Ali?

context: The Hashimiyya movement (a sub-sect of the <a0_0><b5_0>Kaysanites Shia<b5_0/><a0_0/>), led by <b6_0>the <a1_0>Abbasid family<b6_0/><a1_0/>, overthrew the Umayyad caliphate. The Abbasids were members of the <a2_0>Hashim<a2_0/> clan, rivals of the Umayyads, but the word "Hashimiyya" seems to refer specifically to Abu Hashim, a grandson of Ali and son of Muhammad ibn al-Hanafiyya. According to certain traditions, Abu Hashim died in <a3_0>717<a3_0/> in Humeima in the house of Muhammad ibn Ali, the head of the Abbasid family, and before dying named <a4_0><b7_0>Muhammad ibn Ali<b7_0/><a4_0/> as his successor. <b8_0>This tradition<b8_0/> allowed the Abbasids to rally <b9_0>the supporters of the failed revolt of Mukhtar<b9_0/>, who had represented themselves as the supporters of Muhammad ibn al-Hanafiyya.
